segment.source: System settings Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies (Windows 10)
segment.target: System settings Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies security policy setting.

segment.source: System settings: Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies
segment.target: System settings: Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings: Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings: Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines whether digital certificates are processed when software restriction policies are enabled and a user or process attempts to run software with an .exe file name extension.
segment.target: This policy setting determines whether digital certificates are processed when software restriction policies are enabled and a user or process attempts to run software with an .exe file name extension.

segment.source: This security setting enables or disables certificate rules (which are a type of software restriction policy).
segment.target: This security setting enables or disables certificate rules (which are a type of software restriction policy).

segment.source: With a software restriction policy, you can create a certificate rule that allows or disallows Microsoft Authenticode®-signed software to run, based on the digital certificate that is associated with the software.
segment.target: With a software restriction policy, you can create a certificate rule that allows or disallows Microsoft Authenticode®-signed software to run, based on the digital certificate that is associated with the software.

segment.source: For certificate rules to work in software restriction policies, you must enable this security setting.
segment.target: For certificate rules to work in software restriction policies, you must enable this security setting.

segment.source: Enabling certificate rules results in software restriction policies checking a certificate revocation list (CRL) to make sure that the software's certificate and signature are valid.
segment.target: Enabling certificate rules results in software restriction policies checking a certificate revocation list (CRL) to make sure that the software's certificate and signature are valid.

segment.source: When you start signed programs, this setting can decrease system performance.
segment.target: When you start signed programs, this setting can decrease system performance.

segment.source: You can disable CRLs by editing the software restriction policies in the desired GPO.
segment.target: You can disable CRLs by editing the software restriction policies in the desired GPO.

segment.source: In the Trusted Publishers Properties dialog box, clear the Publisher and Timestamp check boxes.
segment.target: In the Trusted Publishers Properties dialog box, clear the Publisher and Timestamp check boxes.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Without the use of software restriction policies, users and device might be exposed to unauthorized software that could include malware.
segment.target: Without the use of software restriction policies, users and device might be exposed to unauthorized software that could include malware.

segment.source: Enable the System settings: Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies setting.
segment.target: Enable the System settings: Use certificate rules on Windows executables for Software Restriction Policies setting.

segment.source: If you enable certificate rules, software restriction policies check a certificate revocation list (CRL) to verify that the software's certificate and signature are valid.
segment.target: If you enable certificate rules, software restriction policies check a certificate revocation list (CRL) to verify that the software's certificate and signature are valid.

segment.source: This checking process may negatively affect performance when signed programs start.
segment.target: This checking process may negatively affect performance when signed programs start.

segment.source: To disable this feature, you can edit the software restriction policies in the appropriate GPO.
segment.target: To disable this feature, you can edit the software restriction policies in the appropriate GPO.

segment.source: In the Trusted Publishers Properties dialog box, clear the Publisher and Timestamp check boxes.
segment.target: In the Trusted Publishers Properties dialog box, clear the Publisher and Timestamp check boxes.
